questions.text: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of vomiting and severe testicular pain for 3 hours. During this time, the patient has had 4–5 episodes of vomiting. He has never had a similar episode in the past and takes no medications. His father died of testicular cancer at the age of 50. His immunizations are up-to-date. He appears anxious and uncomfortable. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nondistended. The right scrotum is firm, erythematous, and swollen. There is severe tenderness to palpation of the right scrotum. The pain persists on elevation of the right testicle. Stroking the inner side of the right thigh fails to elicit elevation of the scrotum. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A urine dipstick test is indicated for various suspected genitourinary conditions, including the diagnosis of epididymitis. Epididymitis manifests with unilateral scrotal pain and swelling, which are features exhibited by this patient as well. However, in cases of epididymitis, the elevation of the affected hemiscrotum reduces pain, which is called a positive Prehn sign. This patient has a negative Prehn sign.

B) CORRECT:

Immediate surgical exploration of the scrotum including detorsion of the affected testis and orchidopexy of both testes is the treatment of choice for testicular torsion. Testicular torsion is a medical emergency and is most likely to occur during the neonatal period and puberty. Twisting of the spermatic cord leads to venous engorgement, which may result in arterial compromise and irreversible damage if the torsion is not resolved within 6–12 hours. Manual testicular detorsion may be attempted if surgery is not available or for immediate pain relief prior to surgery.

See "Differential diagnosis of scrotal pain" table.
Image Description:

Testicular torsion is the twisting of the spermatic cord containing testicular blood vessels, leading to testicular ischemia. Testicular torsion most commonly occurs in the medial direction.

Manual detorsion may be attempted before definitive surgical therapy (orchidopexy) if the duration of symptoms is less than six hours. This involves untwisting the spermatic cord by rotating the testis in a lateral direction.

C) INCORRECT:

Close observation would be indicated for traumatic or idiopathic scrotal edema. However, testicular torsion is a medical emergency that requires urgent intervention to prevent irreversible damage to the testes.

D) INCORRECT:

A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis is used for the diagnosis of various conditions, including inguinal hernias. An inguinal hernia may cause vomiting, a symptom that this patient exhibits. However, an inguinal hernia causes pain in the groin rather than testicular pain. Moreover, it does not cause swelling of the scrotum or an absent cremasteric reflex.

E) INCORRECT:

Doppler ultrasound of the scrotum can confirm testicular torsion in patients with ambiguous clinical findings. In patients with testicular torsion, Doppler ultrasound typically shows twisting of the spermatic cord and reduced perfusion on the affected side. However, the diagnosis can be made clinically in patients with unequivocal findings (e.g., absent cremasteric reflex). Because of the risk for irreversible testicular damage, definitive treatment should not be delayed by further diagnostic workup.

F) INCORRECT:

Ceftriaxone is used in combination with doxycycline to treat epididymitis. Epididymitis manifests with unilateral scrotal pain and swelling, which are features exhibited by this patient as well. However, in cases of epididymitis, elevating the affected hemiscrotum reduces the pain, which is called a positive Prehn sign. This patient has a negative Prehn sign.
questions.hint: This adolescent boy presents with acute testicular pain, a negative Prehn sign (persistence of pain on elevation of the testicle), and an absent cremasteric reflex, indicating testicular torsion.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of progressive left-sided scrotal pain for 4 hours. He describes the pain as throbbing in nature and 6 out of 10 in intensity. He has vomited once on the way to the hospital. He has had pain during urination for the past 4 days. He had an episode of similar pain 1 year ago that resolved spontaneously. He underwent surgery for a left-sided inguinal hernia as a child. He has been sexually active with 2 female partners over the past year and uses condoms inconsistently. He appears anxious. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 94/min, and blood pressure is 124/78 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Examination shows a tender, swollen left testicle and a firm and erythematous left hemiscrotum. The left testicle ascends when the medial portion of the left thigh is stroked. Urine dipstick shows positive leukocyte esterase. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis
Measurement of serum mumps IgG titer

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fluoroquinolones (e.g., levofloxacin) can be used to treat epididymitis in older patients, in whom this condition is most commonly secondary to urinary tract infections. Since epididymitis in young, sexually active male individuals is most frequently caused by sexually transmitted infections such as Chlamydia trachomatis or Neisseria gonorrhoeae, a combination of ceftriaxone and doxycycline is the most appropriate empiric antibiotic treatment for this patient. Moreover, his presentation makes a different step in management necessary.

B) INCORRECT:

CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis is typically used in the workup of an acute abdomen. It may also be used in the workup of suspected torsion of an undescended testis. Imaging modalities such as CT scan, MRI, and scintigraphy play no role in the initial workup of this patient who has symptoms of an acute scrotum and no cryptorchidism.

C) INCORRECT:

Immediate surgical exploration is indicated if clinical features indicate a definitive diagnosis of testicular torsion. Although this patient's presentation increases the likelihood of testicular torsion, the diagnosis of testicular torsion is not yet conclusive at this time because of an intact cremasteric reflex, the absence of a hard and high-riding testis, and the presence of features of epididymitis. A different step in management should be performed first.

D) CORRECT:

While epididymitis is the most likely cause of this patient's acute testicular pain, the most dangerous differential diagnosis is testicular torsion. In patients with acute testicular pain, an absent cremasteric reflex is relatively specific for testicular torsion but the presence of a cremasteric reflex does not rule out the condition. For this patient, a scrotal ultrasound is necessary to definitively rule out testicular torsion. If testicular torsion is not corrected early by surgery, testicular ischemia will result in necrosis and loss of the testicle. Scrotal ultrasound is also performed as a part of the management of epididymitis in order to rule out a scrotal abscess, a common complication that may require surgical drainage.

Risk stratification scores (e.g., TWIST score) can be used to formally assess the risk of testicular torsion. For your exam, it is not necessary to know how to calculate the TWIST score but to follow this principle: always consider testicular torsion in a patient with acute testicular pain and if testicular torsion cannot be ruled out clinically with a high level of certainty, perform a scrotal ultrasound.

E) INCORRECT:

Orchitis can manifest with a unilateral swollen and tender testicle in conjunction with nausea and vomiting. Orchitis may be a complication of infection with the mumps virus, which can be confirmed by positive serology (e.g., IgG antibody titer). However, in mumps orchitis, a sudden onset of fever is expected. Furthermore, the classic course of mumps infection includes a prodromal phase with low-grade fever, respiratory symptoms, malaise, and headache, followed by parotitis, which is not consistent with this patient's clinical presentation.
questions.hint: This patient's high risk sexual behavior, dysuria, and pyuria (positive leukocyte esterase) are consistent with epididymitis but his young age, the sudden onset of scrotal pain, and the presence of vomiting and testicular swelling also increase the likelihood of a condition that can result in permanent morbidity if not detected and treated within 6 hours of symptom onset.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of severe lower abdominal pain, pain in the right groin, nausea, and vomiting for 2 hours. The patient had been playing soccer with friends and started experiencing pain while walking home. He has never experienced similar symptoms before. He has no other history of serious illness and does not take any medications. He appears ill. His temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 140/80 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. The right scrotum appears mildly swollen. There is severe tenderness on palpation of the scrotum that persists with elevation of the testes. Stroking the inner side of the right thigh fails to elicit elevation of the scrotum. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Epididymitis can cause unilateral scrotal pain, swelling, and tenderness. However, the pain is typically gradual in onset and radiates to the flank, and only the epididymis is tender. Although epididymitis does occur in adolescents, it does not typically cause lower abdominal pain, a negative Prehn sign, or an absent cremasteric reflex. In addition, this patient does not have typical clinical features of epididymitis, including a fever, dysuria, and urinary frequency.

B) INCORRECT:

A testicular tumor can cause unilateral scrotal pain and lower abdominal pain, although the pain is more commonly dull than acute, and it typically causes swelling of the testis rather than scrotal swelling. In addition, this condition does not typically cause nausea, vomiting, groin tenderness, or an absent cremasteric reflex. Moreover, this patient does not have a palpable testicular nodule, which is a typical clinical feature of a testicular tumor.

C) INCORRECT:

A strangulated inguinal hernia can cause severe lower abdominal and unilateral scrotal pain, nausea, vomiting, scrotal swelling, and groin tenderness. However, a strangulated hernia does not typically cause a negative Prehn sign or an absent cremasteric reflex. In addition, this patient does not have typical clinical features of a strangulated hernia, including fever and scrotal erythema.

D) INCORRECT:

A hydrocele can cause scrotal swelling. Although one potential cause of a hydrocele is trauma (e.g., from contact sports), hydroceles do not typically cause severe, lower abdominal and unilateral scrotal pain, nausea, vomiting, groin tenderness, and an absent cremasteric reflex. In addition, this patient does not have typical clinical features of a hydrocele, including fluctuance of the scrotal swelling.

E) CORRECT:

This adolescent boy presents with severe, sudden-onset lower abdominal and unilateral scrotal pain, nausea, vomiting, scrotal swelling, testicular tenderness, a negative Prehn sign, and an absent cremasteric reflex, all of which are consistent with a diagnosis of testicular torsion. This condition is a medical emergency and most commonly affects neonates, boys, and young men. Twisting of the spermatic cord leads to venous engorgement, with consequent compromise of the testicular artery and irreversible damage if the torsion is not resolved in the first 6–12 hours. Ultrasound of the scrotum can be performed if the clinical findings are ambiguous; if the clinical findings are definitive, surgical intervention is the most appropriate next step.

If surgical correction of the torsion is not performed emergently, ischemia and infarction of the testicle can occur. During surgery, reduction (untwisting) of the testis is typically performed in conjunction with orchidopexy of both testes.

F) INCORRECT:

A varicocele can cause unilateral scrotal swelling and pain. However, patients with a varicocele are typically asymptomatic or have dull, achy testicular pain rather than severe pain. In addition, varicoceles do not typically cause lower abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, testicular tenderness, or an absent cremasteric reflex. Moreover, this patient does not have typical clinical features of a varicocele, including a sense of heaviness of the affected scrotum, a “bag of worms “ texture on scrotal palpation, and symptoms that worsen with standing or the Valsalva maneuver. Finally, varicoceles most commonly develop in the left testicle.
questions.hint: This patient has a negative Prehn sign (i.e., elevation of the scrotum that does not relieve testicular pain) and an absent cremasteric reflex (i.e., stroking of the inner side of the thigh that fails to elicit elevation of the scrotum).

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents because of a sudden onset of severe pain in the lower abdomen and left groin that started 3 hours ago. The mother reports that the child woke up in the middle of the night because of pain associated with nausea and vomiting. He had one episode of intermittent left groin pain 2 months ago which resolved on its own. He has no other history of serious illness and does not take any medications. His immunizations are up-to-date. The boy looks ill and appears to be in distress. His temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 110/65 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows tenderness to palpation in the lower quadrants. The left scrotum appears elevated and swollen. There is severe, diffuse tenderness on palpation of the left testicle. The right scrotum is normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Orchitis can manifest with a sudden onset of lower abdominal pain, unilateral scrotal pain and swelling, nausea, and vomiting. However, orchitis typically occurs as a complication of viral mumps infection or epididymitis. This patient has no history or typical findings of epididymitis (e.g., signs of lower urinary tract infection), and his immunizations are up to date, so orchitis is unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

A hydrocele can manifest with unilateral scrotal swelling. However, most patients with a hydrocele present with a painless, fluctuant swelling of the scrotum, which this patient does not have. Additionally, a hydrocele has no associated symptoms, so it would not explain the lower abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting observed here.

C) INCORRECT:

Epididymitis can cause unilateral scrotal pain, swelling, and tenderness on palpation. However, the pain typically has an insidious onset and radiates to the flank, whereas this patient presents with a sudden-onset severe scrotal pain that developed 3 hours ago. In addition, epididymitis usually manifests with signs of urinary tract infection, such as dysuria, urinary frequency, and/or urgency, none of which are observed in this case.

D) INCORRECT:

Torsion of the appendix testis can manifest with a sudden onset of lower abdominal pain, unilateral scrotal swelling, and tenderness, all of which are seen in this patient. However, systemic symptoms (e.g., nausea, vomiting) are usually absent, and the physical examination typically shows a palpable tender mass located at the superior or inferior pole of the affected testis. In addition, symptom onset in torsion of the appendix testis is typically insidious, whereas this patient has an acute presentation.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's clinical presentation (sudden onset of severe hypogastric and left inguinal pain, nausea, vomiting) and physical examination findings (hypogastric and testicular tenderness, scrotal elevation and swelling) suggest testicular torsion, which most commonly develops during the neonatal period and puberty. Other characteristic findings of testicular torsion include absent cremasteric reflex and negative Prehn sign. Testicular torsion is a medical emergency and requires prompt surgical exploration with testicular reduction and bilateral orchidopexy (to prevent recurrence), ideally within six hours of symptom onset. In patients with ambiguous clinical findings, Doppler ultrasound of the scrotum can be performed before surgical intervention to confirm the diagnosis. A delay in management can result in irreversible ischemia and necrosis of the testis.

See "Differential diagnosis of scrotal pain" table.

F) INCORRECT:

A varicocele usually manifests with unilateral scrotal swelling and pain (especially on the left side). However, a varicocele typically also manifests with dull and achy scrotal pain, a feeling of heaviness of the affected scrotum, and a soft scrotal mass that resembles a “bag of worms” on palpation, none of which is observed in this case. In addition, patients with varicocele do not have associated systemic symptoms, so it would not explain this patient's nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain.
questions.hint: Stroking the ipsilateral inner thigh of this patient will most likely fail to elicit elevation of the scrotum.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old sexually active man with no significant medical history presents to the emergency department with nausea and sudden onset of severe scrotal pain after his usual morning exercise. He reports no trauma.
He has a temperature of 37.9°C, a blood pressure of 138/89 mm Hg, a heart rate of 110 beats per minute, and a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute. He appears uncomfortable. Mild erythema is evident over the right side of the scrotum, and his right testicle is swollen and tender. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.
Urinalysis and urine microscopy results are normal.
Which one of the following studies would confirm the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

choices.text: Serial physical examinations of the abdomen and scrotum during the next 6 hours
Urine polymerase-chain-reaction testing for chlamydia and gonorrhea infection
Standard gray-scale scrotal ultrasound with serum beta human chorionic gonadotropin and alpha-fetoprotein testing
Serum mumps immunoglobulin M antibody test

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Serial abdominal and scrotal examination is inappropriate if testicular torsion is suspected. The resulting delay in surgical exploration can lead to nonviability of the testicle and loss of fertility.

B) INCORRECT:

Mumps can cause orchitis, and chlamydia and gonorrhea infections are common causes of epididymitis. Both conditions can manifest with scrotal pain, but the symptoms generally progress over hours or days, not minutes. This patient's sudden onset of symptoms is more consistent with testicular torsion. Torsion must be ruled out before these diagnoses are considered.

C) CORRECT:

The differential diagnosis for acute scrotal pain includes testicular torsion, epididymo-orchitis, and necrotizing fasciitis of the perineum (Fournier gangrene). Although all of these conditions require prompt diagnosis and management, testicular torsion is a urological emergency that requires immediate recognition and intervention. It typically manifests with sudden severe scrotal pain accompanied by nausea and vomiting. Physical examination may reveal ipsilateral redness, warmth, and induration of scrotal skin, especially later in the course. The patient’s testicle is usually swollen, exquisitely tender, and high-riding with an abnormal horizontal orientation. Ipsilateral cremasteric reflex is classically absent.

Color Doppler ultrasonography of the scrotum demonstrates an absence of blood flow in testicular torsion and is the most appropriate imaging study to confirm this diagnosis. In some studies, the sensitivity and specificity of this test for testicular torsion approaches 100%. However, lack of immediate access to scrotal ultrasound should not delay surgical exploration, nor should a negative ultrasound result if clinical suspicion for testicular torsion is high.

Key learning point: In a patient with acute scrotal pain, the most appropriate imaging study to aid in the diagnosis of testicular torsion is Doppler ultrasonography of the scrotum.

D) INCORRECT:

Standard gray-scale ultrasound without Doppler imaging is insufficient to rule out testicular torsion because it does not assess blood flow. The distinction is important, because a scrotal ultrasound ordered to rule out a mass may not include Doppler imaging in all centers. Serum beta human chorionic gonadotropin and alpha-fetoprotein are markers found in most patients with germ-cell testicular cancers; they have no role in evaluation of patients with acute scrotal pain.

E) INCORRECT:

Mumps can cause orchitis, and chlamydia and gonorrhea infections are common causes of epididymitis. Both conditions can manifest with scrotal pain, but the symptoms generally progress over hours or days, not minutes. This patient's sudden onset of symptoms is more consistent with testicular torsion. Torsion must be ruled out before these diagnoses are considered.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 10-year-old boy who is fully vaccinated presents to the emergency department 3 hours after being awakened by severe pain in the right lower quadrant. The pain has become more severe during the past hour and has migrated to the patient's right groin. He reports nausea and one episode of nonbloody, nonbilious emesis. He has had no recent illness, fever, or trauma.
His temperature is 37°C, his heart rate is 126 beats per minute, and his blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. His condition is nontoxic, but he is very uncomfortable with movement. His abdomen is nondistended and nontender with normal active bowel sounds.
Genital examination reveals an enlarged, erythematous right hemiscrotum. His right testicle is diffusely tender to palpation, slightly elevated, and lying horizontally. The cremasteric reflex is absent on the right. There is no penile discharge or outward signs of genital trauma.
Analgesia is provided, and the right testicle is rotated medially to laterally; the patient’s symptoms remain unchanged. Scrotal ultrasonography with Doppler flow is limited by patient pain but shows reduced perfusion of the testicle.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Elevate the scrotum and surround it with an ice pack
Administer a dose of ceftriaxone, and start a course of doxycycline
Order a reverse-transcription polymerase chain-reaction (RT-PCR) test for mumps

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cooling and elevation of the scrotum are not appropriate therapeutic interventions for a testicular torsion.

B) CORRECT:

This patient's findings are consistent with acute testicular torsion, a surgical emergency that occurs most commonly in boys aged 7 to 12 years. The classic presentation includes sudden intense scrotal pain, but patients may initially present with referred lower abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. The affected testicle will be diffusely tender, may be elevated, and may also have a transverse orientation. A tender nodule with bluish discoloration may be palpable at the upper pole (blue dot sign). An absent cremasteric reflex is highly concerning for testicular torsion; however, the presence of a cremasteric reflex does not rule out testicular torsion. History and physical examination are often sufficient for an accurate diagnosis.

Ultrasound can aid diagnosis, demonstrating reduced perfusion of the testicle and, in some cases, showing the twisting of the spermatic cord. Reduced perfusion can also be seen when the cause of swelling is a hernia or hydrocele, but in these cases, there should still be a cremasteric reflex.

A 4- to 8-hour window exists between the onset of pain in testicular torsion and the development of significant ischemic damage. To maximize the chance of testicular viability, surgical consultation should not be delayed and should be prioritized.

Manual detorsion, with adequate analgesia, may be attempted while awaiting urgent surgical evaluation. In this case, the detorsion attempt was unsuccessful and urgent definitive surgical repair is required.

Unless definitive care is anticipated to be significantly delayed, manual detorsion should be performed only after adequate analgesia. Even with successful manual detorsion, definitive surgical repair is required.

Key learning point: When a patient presents with a history and physical examination associated with acute testicular torsion, the most appropriate initial management includes prompt surgical consultation (assuming there is no anticipated prolonged delay).

C) INCORRECT:

Ceftriaxone and doxycycline would be appropriate treatment for presumed chlamydia or gonococcal epididymitis. Acute infectious epididymitis can manifest with pain and swelling, but it is localized to the epididymis, not the testicle, which would be in a normal vertical lie when examined.

D) INCORRECT:

A urinalysis and culture would be appropriate for presumed chlamydia or gonococcal epididymitis. Acute infectious epididymitis can manifest with pain and swelling, but it is localized to the epididymis, not the testicle, which would be in a normal vertical lie when examined.

E) INCORRECT:

Testing for mumps typically includes both immunoglobulin testing and reverse-transcription polymerase chain-reaction (RT-PCR) testing. Orchitis can be a complication of mumps, typically associated with fever in postpubertal boys. This patient’s age and lack of preceding illness or fever make mumps unlikely.

Twisting of the spermatic cord leads to venous engorgement, with consequent compromise of the testicular artery and irreversible damage if the torsion is not resolved in the first 6–12 hours. Ultrasound of the scrotum can be performed if the clinical findings are ambiguous; if the clinical findings are definitive, surgical intervention is the most appropriate next step. If surgical correction of the torsion is not performed emergently, ischemia and infarction of the testicle can occur. During surgery, reduction (untwisting) of the testis is typically performed in conjunction with orchidopexy of both testes.

Key learning point: Testicular torsion presents with sudden, severe scrotal pain, swelling, absent cremasteric reflex, and is a surgical emergency requiring prompt intervention to prevent testicular ischemia.

E) INCORRECT:

A varicocele can cause unilateral scrotal swelling and pain. However, patients with a varicocele are typically asymptomatic or have dull, achy testicular pain rather than severe pain. In addition, varicoceles do not typically cause lower abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, testicular tenderness, or an absent cremasteric reflex. Moreover, this patient does not have typical clinical features of a varicocele, including a sense of heaviness of the affected scrotum, a “bag of worms “ texture on scrotal palpation, and symptoms that worsen with standing or the Valsalva maneuver. Finally, varicoceles most commonly develop in the left testicle.
questions.hint: This patient has a negative Prehn sign (i.e., elevation of the scrotum that does not relieve testicular pain) and an absent cremasteric reflex (i.e., stroking of the inner side of the thigh that fails to elicit elevation of the scrotum).

questions.text: A 19-year-old sexually active man with no significant medical history presents to the emergency department with nausea and sudden onset of severe scrotal pain after his usual morning exercise. He reports no trauma. He has a temperature of 37.9°C, a blood pressure of 138/89 mm Hg, a heart rate of 110 beats per minute, and a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute. He appears uncomfortable. Mild erythema is evident over the right side of the scrotum, and his right testicle is swollen and tender. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable. Urinalysis and urine microscopy results are normal. Which one of the following studies would confirm the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

choices.text: Serial physical examinations of the abdomen and scrotum during the next 6 hours
Urine polymerase-chain-reaction testing for chlamydia and gonorrhea infection
Standard gray-scale scrotal ultrasound with serum beta human chorionic gonadotropin and alpha-fetoprotein testing
Serum mumps immunoglobulin M antibody test

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Serial abdominal and scrotal examination is inappropriate if testicular torsion is suspected. The resulting delay in surgical exploration can lead to nonviability of the testicle and loss of fertility.

B) INCORRECT:

Mumps can cause orchitis, and chlamydia and gonorrhea infections are common causes of epididymitis. Both conditions can manifest with scrotal pain, but the symptoms generally progress over hours or days, not minutes. This patient's sudden onset of symptoms is more consistent with testicular torsion. Torsion must be ruled out before these diagnoses are considered.

C) CORRECT:

Testicular torsion is a urological emergency that requires immediate recognition and intervention. It typically manifests with sudden severe scrotal pain accompanied by nausea and vomiting. Physical examination may reveal ipsilateral redness, warmth, and induration of scrotal skin, especially later in the course. The patient’s testicle is usually swollen, exquisitely tender, and high-riding with an abnormal horizontal orientation. Ipsilateral cremasteric reflex is classically absent.

Color Doppler ultrasonography of the scrotum demonstrates an absence of blood flow in testicular torsion and is the most appropriate imaging study to confirm this diagnosis. In some studies, the sensitivity and specificity of this test for testicular torsion approaches 100%. However, lack of immediate access to scrotal ultrasound should not delay surgical exploration, nor should a negative ultrasound result if clinical suspicion for testicular torsion is high.

Key learning point: In a patient with acute scrotal pain, the most appropriate imaging study to aid in the diagnosis of testicular torsion is Doppler ultrasonography of the scrotum.

D) INCORRECT:

Standard gray-scale ultrasound without Doppler imaging is insufficient to rule out testicular torsion because it does not assess blood flow. The distinction is important, because a scrotal ultrasound ordered to rule out a mass may not include Doppler imaging in all centers. Serum beta human chorionic gonadotropin and alpha-fetoprotein are markers found in most patients with germ-cell testicular cancers; they have no role in evaluation of patients with acute scrotal pain.

E) INCORRECT:

Mumps can cause orchitis, and chlamydia and gonorrhea infections are common causes of epididymitis. Both conditions can manifest with scrotal pain, but the symptoms generally progress over hours or days, not minutes. This patient's sudden onset of symptoms is more consistent with testicular torsion. Torsion must be ruled out before these diagnoses are considered.
questions.hint: The differential diagnosis for acute scrotal pain includes testicular torsion, epididymo-orchitis, and necrotizing fasciitis of the perineum (Fournier gangrene).

questions.text:
A 17-year-old boy presents with sudden severe left scrotal pain that awoke him from sleep. He denies urinary frequency, dysuria, fever, chills, or abnormal discharge. The left hemiscrotum is swollen and erythematous. The left testis rests higher compared to the right, and gentle manipulation worsens the pain.
Which of the following diagnoses is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Torsion of the appendix testis causes localized tenderness at the upper pole of the testis and may show a “blue dot” sign, neither of which are noted here. The sudden, severe pain and high-riding testis suggest more extensive testicular involvement, not isolated appendage torsion.

B) INCORRECT:

Inguinal hernias often present with a groin bulge, exacerbated by activities increasing intra-abdominal pressure, and may cause gastrointestinal symptoms if strangulated. The absence of a groin mass and the high-riding testis are not typical of an inguinal hernia, which usually does not cause direct testicular manipulation pain.

C) INCORRECT:

Epididymitis typically presents with gradual onset scrotal pain and urinary symptoms, such as dysuria, which are absent here. Pain relief upon scrotal elevation (positive Prehn’s sign) contrasts with the worsening pain upon manipulation. The high-riding testis is inconsistent with epididymitis, which usually does not alter testicular position.

D) CORRECT:

Testicular torsion manifests with the twisting of the spermatic cord, leading to acute vascular compromise and severe unilateral scrotal pain. This condition is common in adolescents and often occurs suddenly, sometimes during sleep. Anatomical factors, such as the bell clapper deformity, predispose the testis to abnormal mobility, causing it to rest higher than the contralateral side. The clinical presentation includes scrotal swelling, erythema, and increased pain upon manipulation, all indicative of ischemia due to torsion.

Key learning point: Acute scrotal pain with an elevated, tender testis and scrotal edema in a young male is highly suggestive of testicular torsion, a surgical emergency requiring prompt intervention.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old man presents with sudden, severe pain in his left testicle for the past two hours. He denies trauma. He appears very uncomfortable. Examination reveals a swollen, exquisitely tender left scrotum. The left spermatic cord feels twisted, and the ipsilateral cremasteric reflex is absent. Doppler ultrasound is not immediately available.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

MRI provides detailed imaging but is time-consuming and not practical in acute scrotal emergencies like testicular torsion. The clinical presentation strongly suggests torsion, requiring immediate intervention to restore blood flow. MRI would delay treatment, reducing the chance of testicular salvage.

B) INCORRECT:

Broad-spectrum antibiotics treat infections like epididymitis or orchitis, not testicular torsion. The sudden severe pain, twisted spermatic cord, and absent cremasteric reflex indicate torsion, necessitating surgical intervention. Antibiotics would not address the ischemia and could delay necessary surgery.

C) INCORRECT:

NSAIDs reduce inflammation and pain but do not address vascular compromise in testicular torsion. The acute severe pain, twisted spermatic cord, and absent cremasteric reflex indicate compromised blood flow. Observation delays intervention, increasing the risk of ischemic injury.

D) CORRECT:

Testicular torsion involves twisting of the spermatic cord, compromising blood supply to the testis and risking ischemia and infarction. The patient's sudden severe scrotal pain, twisted spermatic cord, and absent cremasteric reflex are classic signs of torsion. Immediate surgical exploration allows for detorsion and bilateral orchiopexy, crucial for testicular salvage. The time-sensitive nature of testicular viability, typically within six hours of symptom onset, necessitates urgent intervention, especially when Doppler ultrasound is unavailable.

Key learning point: In cases of suspected testicular torsion, characterized by acute scrotal pain and absent cremasteric reflex, immediate surgical consultation is crucial to prevent testicular loss.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old boy presents with sudden onset of left scrotal pain for the last 8 hours. The pain is moderate, localized, and reproducible with gentle palpation at the superior aspect of the left testis. On examination, the cremasteric reflex is intact, and the scrotal skin is slightly erythematous. There is no fever (see report).
Doppler ultrasound of the testis: Normal blood flow to the left testis
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Varicocele presents as a painless or mildly uncomfortable mass, often described as a 'bag of worms,' with a chronic dull ache. It is not associated with sudden, localized pain or normal testicular blood flow on ultrasound, as seen in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

Torsion of the testicular appendage is common in pre-adolescent boys and involves twisting of a vestigial remnant at the upper pole of the testis. It presents with localized pain reproducible on palpation at the superior aspect of the testis. The cremasteric reflex remains intact, and Doppler ultrasound shows normal testicular blood flow, distinguishing it from testicular torsion. The absence of systemic symptoms like fever and mild scrotal erythema further support this diagnosis. Management is supportive, focusing on pain control and scrotal support, as the condition is generally benign and self-limiting.

Key learning point: Torsion of a testicular appendage presents with localized tenderness at the superior pole of the testis and can cause scrotal edema and redness, distinguishing it from testicular torsion and other scrotal pathologies.

C) INCORRECT:

Epididymitis typically presents with gradual onset pain localized to the epididymis, often with fever or dysuria. It is uncommon in 10-year-old boys without urinary tract abnormalities. Doppler ultrasound usually shows increased blood flow, unlike the normal flow seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

Testicular torsion presents with sudden, severe pain, often with nausea and vomiting. It is characterized by an absent cremasteric reflex and reduced or absent blood flow on Doppler ultrasound. The presence of a normal cremasteric reflex and normal blood flow in this patient makes testicular torsion unlikely.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old boy presents with sudden onset of severe left scrotal pain that began 4 hours ago. He rates the pain as 9 out of 10 and describes it as constant. He denies dysuria or urinary frequency. He has no prior medical history. Examination shows the left testis lying high in the scrotum, with exquisite tenderness and significant swelling. Light stroking of the inner thigh does not cause testicular elevation.
What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Observation and analgesics are inappropriate for testicular torsion, which requires immediate intervention. Delaying treatment risks testicular ischemia and infarction, as the condition is time-sensitive and necessitates prompt surgical exploration.

B) INCORRECT:

Intravenous antibiotics are indicated for infections like epididymitis or orchitis, which present with urinary symptoms and fever. The sudden onset of severe pain, high-riding testis, and absent cremasteric reflex suggest testicular torsion, not an infection.

C) CORRECT:

Testicular torsion involves twisting of the spermatic cord, leading to compromised blood supply and potential ischemia. It presents with sudden, severe scrotal pain, a high-riding testis, and an absent cremasteric reflex. Immediate surgical exploration is crucial within the critical time window to detorse the testis and perform orchiopexy, reducing the risk of testicular loss. Delaying treatment increases the likelihood of irreversible damage.

Key learning point: Testicular torsion is a surgical emergency requiring immediate scrotal exploration to salvage the testis; Doppler ultrasound should not delay surgical intervention if torsion is suspected.

D) INCORRECT:

MRI provides detailed anatomical information but is not suitable for acute scrotal emergencies like testicular torsion due to its longer acquisition time and limited availability. Doppler ultrasound is preferred for rapid assessment of testicular blood flow in such cases.

questions.text: You are seeing a 13-year-old boy who is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of vomiting and severe testicular pain for 3 hours. He has had 4–5 episodes of vomiting during this time. He appears anxious and uncomfortable. His temperature is 37°C, pulse is 90/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. The abdomen is soft and nondistended. The right scrotum is firm, erythematous, and swollen, with severe tenderness to palpation. The pain does not improve with elevation of the right testicle. Stroking the inner side of the right thigh does not elicit elevation of the scrotum. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A urine dipstick test is indicated for various suspected genitourinary conditions, including the diagnosis of epididymitis. Epididymitis manifests with unilateral scrotal pain and swelling, which are features exhibited by this patient as well. However, in cases of epididymitis, the elevation of the affected hemiscrotum reduces pain, which is called a positive Prehn sign. This patient has a negative Prehn sign.

B) INCORRECT:

Close observation would be indicated for traumatic or idiopathic scrotal edema. However, testicular torsion is a medical emergency that requires urgent intervention to prevent irreversible damage to the testes.

C) INCORRECT:

Ceftriaxone is used in combination with doxycycline to treat epididymitis. Epididymitis manifests with unilateral scrotal pain and swelling, which are features exhibited by this patient as well. However, in cases of epididymitis, elevating the affected hemiscrotum reduces the pain, which is called a positive Prehn sign. This patient has a negative Prehn sign.

D) CORRECT:

Immediate surgical exploration of the scrotum including detorsion of the affected testis and orchidopexy of both testes is the treatment of choice for testicular torsion. Testicular torsion is a medical emergency and is most likely to occur during the neonatal period and puberty. Twisting of the spermatic cord leads to venous engorgement, which may result in arterial compromise and irreversible damage if the torsion is not resolved within 6–12 hours. Manual testicular detorsion may be attempted if surgery is not available or for immediate pain relief prior to surgery.

See "Differential diagnosis of scrotal pain" table.

Key learning point: Testicular torsion is a surgical emergency requiring immediate scrotal exploration to prevent irreversible testicular damage, ideally within 6–12 hours of symptom onset.
Image Description:

Testicular torsion is the twisting of the spermatic cord containing testicular blood vessels, leading to testicular ischemia. Testicular torsion most commonly occurs in the medial direction.

Manual detorsion may be attempted before definitive surgical therapy (orchidopexy) if the duration of symptoms is less than six hours. This involves untwisting the spermatic cord by rotating the testis in a lateral direction.

E) INCORRECT:

A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis is used for the diagnosis of various conditions, including inguinal hernias. An inguinal hernia may cause vomiting, a symptom that this patient exhibits. However, an inguinal hernia causes pain in the groin rather than testicular pain. Moreover, it does not cause swelling of the scrotum or an absent cremasteric reflex.
questions.hint: This adolescent boy presents with acute testicular pain, a negative Prehn sign (persistence of pain on elevation of the testicle), and an absent cremasteric reflex, indicating testicular torsion.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with acute-onset left testicular pain and nausea that began 4 hours ago. Physical examination reveals scrotal swelling, a testis that is firm to palpation and elevated compared to the contralateral side, and an absent cremasteric reflex. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Immediate urology consult for surgical exploration

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Scrotal ultrasound is indicated if clinical findings are inconclusive. This patient's clinical presentation is highly suggestive of testicular torsion, which requires immediate intervention.

B) INCORRECT:

Manual detorsion may provide temporary relief but should not delay definitive surgical management. Even if detorsion is successful, surgical exploration is still required.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has multiple features of testicular torsion, including scrotal swelling, firm testis, absent cremasteric reflex, and testicular elevation. Patients with a high clinical probability of torsion should proceed directly to surgical exploration without imaging delays to optimize testicular salvage within the 6-hour window.

D) INCORRECT:

Laboratory studies are not required to diagnose suspected testicular torsion. Urinalysis is primarily useful when considering epididymitis as an alternative diagnosis, but this patient's clinical presentation strongly suggests torsion.

E) INCORRECT:

IV antibiotics and admission are indicated for severe epididymitis with systemic symptoms or complications. This patient's acute presentation with absent cremasteric reflex, scrotal swelling, and elevated testis is characteristic of testicular torsion, which requires immediate intervention rather than medical management with antibiotics.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents to the emergency department with acute-onset left scrotal pain that began 3 hours ago while playing basketball. He rates the pain as 9/10 and reports nausea and one episode of vomiting. Physical examination shows a tender, swollen left testis positioned higher than the right. The cremasteric reflex is absent on the left. The pain does not improve upon manual elevation of the left hemiscrotum. The patient denies dysuria, urinary frequency, or urethral discharge. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acute epididymitis typically presents with gradual-onset pain over days, a positive Prehn sign (pain relief with scrotal elevation), and urinary symptoms, such as dysuria and frequency. This patient's acute onset of pain, negative Prehn sign, and absence of urinary symptoms point towards a different diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Complicated inguinal hernia typically presents with visible or palpable groin protrusion, and bowel sounds may be audible over the scrotum. The clinical findings of a high-riding testis and an absent cremasteric reflex are not more consistent with a different diagnosis.

C) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient's presentation is classic for testicular torsion with sudden-onset, severe, unilateral scrotal pain, a high-riding testis, an absent cremasteric reflex, and a negative Prehn sign (absence of pain relief with scrotal elevation). The acute onset of pain during physical activity, nausea, and vomiting are typical features that support this diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Testicular tumors typically present as painless masses with slow progression. This patient's acute-onset severe pain and physical examination findings are not consistent with a testicular malignancy.

E) INCORRECT:

While nephrolithiasis can present with pain radiating into the scrotum, the physical examination findings of a high-riding, swollen testis and an absent cremasteric reflex suggest a different condition.

questions.text: A 17-year-old patient presents to the emergency department with severe left scrotal pain that began 90 minutes prior during basketball practice. The patient reports nausea and one episode of vomiting. Examination shows a swollen, firm left testis in a high-riding position with absent cremasteric reflex. The on-call urologist indicates that surgical exploration will be delayed by 45 minutes due to a concurrent emergency. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Transfer immediately to operating room without further intervention
Obtain urgent scrotal duplex ultrasound before proceeding
Administer parenteral analgesics and await surgical availability
Perform manual detorsion by rotating medially toward the midline
Perform manual detorsion by rotating laterally toward the thigh

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While immediate surgery is ideal, the 45-minute delay provides an opportunity for manual detorsion that could restore testicular blood flow. Manual intervention should not delay transfer, but can be attempted because of the surgical delay.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient's clinical presentation indicates a high likelihood of torsion, and imaging would unnecessarily delay treatment. Patients with a high clinical suspicion can proceed directly to surgical exploration without prior imaging confirmation.

C) INCORRECT:

While pain management should be initiated, waiting without attempting detorsion wastes valuable time because manual intervention could potentially restore testicular blood flow and improve outcomes prior to surgical intervention.

D) INCORRECT:

Manual detorsion should initially be performed by rotating laterally toward the thigh, as most torsions occur toward the midline. Medial rotation is only attempted if lateral rotation fails to provide symptom relief.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- Given the high likelihood of torsion and a surgical delay, manual detorsion should be attempted by rotating the testis laterally toward the thigh. Lateral rotation is the initial technique of choice because two-thirds of torsions occur toward the midline. Manual detorsion with lateral rotation may provide immediate symptom relief and restore blood flow while awaiting definitive surgical management.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with a 3-hour history of severe, unrelenting left testicular pain that woke him from sleep. He also reports nausea. He denies any recent trauma or sexual activity. On examination, his left testicle is exquisitely tender, swollen, and positioned higher than the right. Which of the following additional physical examination findings is most likely to be present in this patient?

choices.text: Relief of pain with scrotal elevation
Absence of the ipsilateral cremasteric reflex
Tenderness localized to the posterior aspect of the testis
A palpable cough impulse at the external inguinal ring

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Positive transillumination occurs when light passes through a fluid-filled scrotal mass, such as a hydrocele or spermatocele. A torsed testicle is a solid, edematous, and ischemic organ, which will block the passage of light, resulting in negative transillumination. The clinical picture of severe, acute pain is also inconsistent with a simple hydrocele.

B) INCORRECT:

Relief of pain with scrotal elevation, known as a positive Prehn's sign, is classically associated with epididymitis. In contrast, testicular torsion typically shows a negative Prehn's sign, where pain is either unchanged or worsened with elevation of the testicle. The patient's presentation of sudden, severe pain and a high-riding testicle is not consistent with epididymitis.

C) CORRECT:

Testicular torsion is a urologic emergency caused by the twisting of the spermatic cord, which leads to venous congestion and subsequent arterial ischemia of the testis. The absence of the cremasteric reflex is the most sensitive physical exam finding for testicular torsion. This reflex is mediated by the genitofemoral nerve; stroking the inner thigh normally causes contraction of the cremasteric muscle and elevation of the ipsilateral testicle. In torsion, the neural pathways within the twisted cord are disrupted, leading to an absent reflex. Its presence makes torsion highly unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Tenderness localized to the posterior and superior aspect of the testis is a hallmark of acute epididymitis, as this is the anatomical location of the epididymis. In testicular torsion, the entire testicle undergoes ischemia, leading to diffuse, exquisite tenderness rather than focal tenderness in a specific region.

E) INCORRECT:

A palpable cough impulse is a characteristic finding of an indirect inguinal hernia, where increased intra-abdominal pressure forces intestinal contents into the inguinal canal. While an incarcerated hernia can cause testicular pain, this patient's presentation with a high-riding testicle without a palpable bulge is more indicative of a different scrotal emergency.
questions.hint: This patient’s clinical features are most likely consistent with testicular torsion.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with a 3-hour history of severe, unrelenting left testicular pain that woke him from sleep. He also reports one episode of vomiting. He denies any recent trauma, sexual activity, or urinary symptoms. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), and his pulse is 110/min. Physical examination reveals a swollen, exquisitely tender left testis that is positioned high in the scrotum with a transverse lie. The cremasteric reflex is absent on the left side. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic study?

choices.text: CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Testicular torsion is a urologic emergency caused by twisting of the spermatic cord, which compromises blood supply to the testicle. Duplex ultrasonography is the diagnostic imaging modality of choice because it is rapid, non-invasive, and highly sensitive and specific. It will demonstrate absent or decreased arterial flow to the affected testis, confirming the diagnosis. Time is critical, as the risk of infarction and subsequent orchiectomy increases significantly after 6 hours of ischemia.

B) INCORRECT:

A urinalysis is often performed in the workup of scrotal pain to evaluate for infectious etiologies like epididymitis or a urinary tract infection, which would show pyuria or bacteriuria. While it can be a useful adjunctive test, the patient's afebrile status, lack of urinary symptoms, and classic physical exam findings make an infectious cause much less likely than torsion. It is not the most appropriate next step to diagnose this time-sensitive condition.

C) INCORRECT:

Radionuclide scrotal imaging can assess testicular perfusion and would show a photopenic, or 'cold,' area in the affected testis in cases of torsion. However, this study is less readily available in most emergency departments, is more time-consuming to perform, and exposes the patient to radiation.

D) INCORRECT:

A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis is not indicated for the primary evaluation of acute testicular pain. It is not a sensitive modality for assessing testicular blood flow or scrotal pathology. While it could identify other causes of referred pain, such as a ureteral stone, this patient's physical examination points directly to an intrascrotal process, making this an inappropriate initial diagnostic study.
questions.hint: The combination of acute, severe testicular pain with a high-riding testis, transverse lie, and an absent cremasteric reflex is highly suggestive of testicular torsion.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with a 3-hour history of severe, constant left testicular pain that woke him from sleep. He has nausea. He has not had any recent trauma, sexual activity, or urinary symptoms. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F). Physical examination reveals a swollen, tender left testicle that is high-riding with a transverse lie. The cremasteric reflex is absent on the left, and elevation of the scrotum worsens the pain. The urinalysis is normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Immediate urologic consultation for surgical exploration
Attempt manual detorsion in the emergency department

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A testicular Doppler ultrasound is the imaging modality of choice to confirm testicular torsion by demonstrating decreased or absent blood flow. However, in a patient with a high clinical suspicion and classic physical exam findings, obtaining imaging should not delay definitive management, as time is critical to preserving testicular viability. In this case, the diagnosis is made clinically.

B) CORRECT:

Due to the risk of testicular ischemia and infarction, immediate surgical exploration is the standard of care for testicular torsion, which is caused by twisting of the spermatic cord that cuts off blood supply to the testicle. The goal is to detorse the testicle and perform a bilateral orchiopexy to prevent recurrence. Testicular salvage rates are high if surgery is performed within 6 hours of symptom onset.

C) INCORRECT:

Manual detorsion is a reasonable temporizing measure that can be attempted at the bedside while preparing for surgery. However, it is not the definitive treatment, as it may be unsuccessful or incomplete, and the testicle can easily retorse. All patients, even those who undergo successful manual detorsion, require surgical exploration and orchiopexy to prevent recurrence.

D) INCORRECT:

Ceftriaxone and doxycycline are appropriate for treating epididymitis in a sexually active male younger than 35. However, this patient's presentation is inconsistent with epididymitis. The absence of fever, urinary symptoms, and pyuria on urinalysis, along with the presence of a negative Prehn's sign and an absent cremasteric reflex, all suggest a non-infectious etiology.

E) INCORRECT:

While providing analgesia with morphine is an important part of management, observation is contraindicated. Testicular torsion is a time-sensitive surgical emergency. Delaying definitive treatment by observing the patient will lead to irreversible testicular ischemia and necrosis, resulting in the loss of the testicle.
questions.hint: The combination of acute, severe testicular pain with a high-riding testis, transverse lie, absent cremasteric reflex, and negative Prehn sign is consistent with testicular torsion.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department due to a 3-hour history of severe, right-sided scrotal pain that woke him from sleep. He also reports nausea. He denies any recent trauma, fever, or dysuria. On examination, the right testicle is exquisitely tender, swollen, and positioned higher than the left. The scrotum is erythematous. Which of the following additional findings would most strongly support the suspected diagnosis?

choices.text: Absence of the ipsilateral cremasteric reflex
Relief of pain with scrotal elevation
Tenderness localized to the posterior aspect of the testis
A palpable, non-reducible mass in the inguinal canal

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's clinical presentation is classic for testicular torsion. The cremasteric reflex, which involves the elevation of the testicle in response to stroking the inner thigh, is mediated by the genitofemoral nerve. In testicular torsion, the twisting of the spermatic cord compromises both the testicular artery and the genitofemoral nerve. Consequently, the absence of this reflex on the affected side is a highly sensitive physical examination finding for testicular torsion. The combination of acute pain, a high-riding testis, and an absent cremasteric reflex necessitates urgent surgical exploration to prevent testicular necrosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Transillumination is a technique used to differentiate cystic from solid scrotal masses. A fluid-filled structure, such as a hydrocele, will transilluminate. A solid mass, such as a testicle or tumor, will not. Although a small reactive hydrocele can sometimes accompany testicular torsion, transillumination is not a primary diagnostic finding for torsion itself, which involves a solid, ischemic organ.

C) INCORRECT:

This describes a positive Prehn sign, which is a classic finding in epididymitis. In epididymitis, elevating the scrotum can provide pain relief by reducing tension on the inflamed epididymis. In testicular torsion, this maneuver typically does not relieve the pain and may even worsen it (negative Prehn sign).

D) INCORRECT:

Tenderness localized to the posterior aspect of the testis is a characteristic finding of epididymitis, as the epididymis is situated there. This patient has diffuse, exquisite tenderness of the entire testicle, which is more consistent with global ischemia from torsion than with localized inflammation of the epididymis.

E) INCORRECT:

This finding is characteristic of an incarcerated inguinal hernia, which can manifest with scrotal pain and swelling. However, the physical examination findings in the stem suggest pathology of the testicle itself, such as its high position and diffuse tenderness, rather than a separate mass originating in the inguinal canal.
questions.hint: The acute onset of severe scrotal pain in an adolescent, especially with a high-riding testicle, is highly suspicious for a urologic emergency involving the twisting of the spermatic cord.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with a 3-hour history of severe left testicular pain that woke him from sleep. He also reports nausea. He denies any recent trauma, fever, or urinary symptoms. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), his pulse is 110/min, and his blood pressure is 128/76 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a swollen, erythematous, and exquisitely tender left hemiscrotum. The left testis is positioned higher than the right and has a transverse lie. The cremasteric reflex is absent on the left side. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Urinalysis and urine culture are useful for diagnosing infectious causes of scrotal pain, such as epididymitis or orchitis, in which pyuria and bacteriuria would be expected. This patient's lack of urinary symptoms and fever, along with the presence of a high-riding testis with an absent cremasteric reflex, make an infectious cause much less likely. These tests should not delay definitive management for suspected torsion.

B) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is classic for testicular torsion, a urologic emergency caused by twisting of the spermatic cord, which cuts off the blood supply to the testicle. Key findings include acute severe pain, a high-riding testis with a transverse lie, and an absent cremasteric reflex. Given the high clinical suspicion and the time-sensitive nature of the condition, the most appropriate next step is immediate surgical exploration to confirm the diagnosis, detorse the testicle, and perform orchiopexy to prevent recurrence. Testicular salvage rates are highest (> 90%) if surgery is performed within 6 hours of symptom onset. Bilateral orchiopexy is typically performed because the contralateral testis is also at risk due to the underlying anatomical predisposition.

C) INCORRECT:

While analgesia is appropriate to manage this patient's severe pain, initiating antibiotics would be the primary treatment for epididymitis, not testicular torsion. The clinical findings are not consistent with an infectious process. Relying on this management would fail to address the underlying testicular ischemia and would lead to irreversible damage and loss of the testicle.

D) INCORRECT:

Scrotal Doppler ultrasonography is the imaging modality of choice to evaluate for testicular torsion when the diagnosis is uncertain, as it can show absent or decreased blood flow to the affected testis. However, for a patient with classic history and physical examination findings that are highly suggestive of torsion, obtaining imaging would cause an unnecessary delay and decrease the chance of testicular salvage.

E) INCORRECT:

Manual detorsion, typically by rotating the testis outward (like opening a book), may be attempted as a temporizing measure while preparing for surgery. However, it is not the definitive treatment, is often unsuccessful due to pain and swelling, and does not correct the underlying anatomical defect that predisposes to torsion.
questions.hint: Acute, severe testicular pain, a high-riding testis with a transverse lie, and an absent cremasteric reflex are highly suggestive of testicular torsion, a time-sensitive surgical emergency.
